item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Welcome to Ashayen Centre
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to Ashayen Centre!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Largest educational and physiotherapy centre in Kanpur for persons with mental and physical disabilities.

item.title: What we do
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded: Over 50,000 people in Kanpur, India have neurological differences. At Ashayen strive to reach out to an increasing number of this population so that they can develop the capability to contribute to society. We provide a range of services to enable well-rounded development of the child. Our teachers strive to find the child's strengths and build on them, be it crafts, english, fine arts or mathematics. Preschool and K-12 School – The Curriculum of the covers a whole range of a normal school learning along with Self Help skills like: eating, drinking, bathing, dressing and undressing. We include activities that make students as independent as possible in daily life. Teaching depends on individual learning patterns and individual teaching goals are outlined for each child. We have a low teacher to student ratio at 1:8 in each class, with much of teaching being done in one-on-one teaching sessions. Vocational Training - The children who are unable to carry on a school syllabus are put in this section. The focus is on functional learning, which includes survival cooking. The Pre Vocational class imparts knowledge on concepts used in day-to-day life: money, time, calendar and weight. The students are taken on field trips to the post office, banks, malls and restaurants. They also learn to use their hands – weaving, candle making, grinding, packing, block printing and paper bag making.  Depending on the ability of the students they are taught fine motor activities they are taught different crafts. Physiotherapy - All the children who need therapy get it on a daily basis. The students have gross motor sessions, Physical Training exercises and Yoga for their physical development.  Regular assessments are done to chart the physical progress of the children. Infant Screening - Paediatricians screen Babies for signs of Cerebral Palsy and other developmental delays. Infant Stimulation and Early Intervention Program - takes care of children less than two years old.  The staff, which includes senior physiotherapists and a trained special educator, sees that the child gets help in all areas of development.  Catching them young is very important and the doctors that refer them to us are becoming increasingly aware of this. Retraining of the brain can happen when the child is very young. Parents Counselling – We assist parents in accepting their child’s problem and then provide guidance for them to cope with it. The Staff provides support to parents by addressing various concerns and making them feel at ease with their child’s disability. Speech Therapy  - Speech is an associated problem with most developmental delays.  The child is taught to communicate and express from very young. Assessment and Testing: Intelligence tests are done whenever necessary.  All areas of the child are assessed when the child is admitted and a customized teaching plan is formulated. Occupational Therapy: This treatment focuses on helping people achieve independence in various aspects of their lives. OT can help to improve their cognitive, physical and motor skills and enhance their self-esteem and sense of accomplishment. Outreach Centres (in Swaroop Nagar and Kidwai Nagar): There are two sub-centres in different parts of Kanpur. These centres provide accessibility to parents that otherwise would be unable to bring their child to main centre.  These centres are a blessing for parents, as the city does not have an adequate transport system.

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
The desire to do something for children with disabilities led our Founders to establish, Ashayen Centre, earlier known as The Spastics Centre, Kanpur. We have been serving children and young adults with disabilities since 1990. Ashayen began primarily for children with Cerebral Palsy, but we have broadened our scope over the years to include children with Mental Retardation, Autism and Multiple Disabilities. When it began, ours was the first centre of its kind in Uttar Pradesh. Seeing the progress our children make over the years has proved that “disability does not mean inability”. For society and parents who considered children with handicaps as a burden, our students are an example that with proper training and rehabilitation they can contribute to society. Ashayen, (which means “hopes” in Hindi) is a beacon for hundreds of families in Kanpur, a city that greatly lacks educational and other services for children with intellectual and physical disabilities. When we started in 1990, we had just 21 children. With growing awareness and support from foreign and local donors we are fortunate to be serving more children and young adults each year. In 2012, there were over 250 children in the Physiotherapy department and 125 in the school section. We have been providing services at minimal fees as most of our students come from poor families. Our services, in education and physiotherapy, compare with the best available in India. Ashayen specializes in physiotherapy for those with cerebral palsy and are continually building expertise in handling other disabilities as well. The centre is a place where children from all strata of society, irrespective of race or religion, to engage in learning together. Looking forward, Ashayen strives to reach out to more of this underserved population and continually improve its services. The future plan is to establish more sub centres in neighbouring areas and creating an effective network of outreach centres. The long-term vision is to offer its expertise to surrounding rural areas and smaller towns. Additionally, we would like to become a Resource institution that imparts training to caregivers, teachers and therapists.   Our Affiliations With our long-term association, guidance and training from: Courage Centre, Minneapolis, USA, the Indian Institute of Cerebral Palsy (IICP), Kolkata and Spastic Centre of Northern India (now called AADI), Ashayen Centre continues to incorporate better equipment and medicines to enable them to reach their maximum potential.
  • Registered Under: Societies Act 1860
  • National Trust, Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment
  • Viklang Kalyan Vibhag, Government of Uttar Pradesh
  • Regd. No. 6120(N) Income Tax Exemption 80G of 1961
  • Affiliated to Indian Institute of Cerebral Palsy (IICP), Kolkata

item.title: Contact Us
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
Visitors are always welcome! Timings: 9am - 2pm on weekdays (Summer and Winter Timings may vary) Email: sckanpur@gmail.com Phone:  0512-2350549 Address: Ashayen, The Spastics Centre, Bal Bhavan, 16/99 A Phool Bagh, Kanpur – 208001
Public Holidays when the Centre will be closed ***(Please show text below only if someone clicks)*** Holidays on fixed dates:
Republic Day – 26th January
Independence Day – 15th August
Gandhi Jayanti – 2nd October
Ambedkar Jayanti
Christmas – 25th December
New Year’s – 1st JanuaryHolidays with varying dates Guru Nanak Jayanti
Basant Panchami
Mahashivratri Holi Ramnavami Raksha Bandhan Janamashtmi Id- ul- Fitr Dushera Deepawali

item.title: Support Us
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded: The generosity of our donors has helped us to grow from an organization serving 21 children, to one serving 100's. We have big aspirations for the coming years: to improve our facilities, gain more expertise in the field, and also to reach out to a larger number of this population since there are still thousands of children with disabilities in Kanpur city alone, that have never chance to getting an education. To enable us to make a larger and more meaningful difference everyday, please donate today. "Give as the rose gives perfume" - Swami Vivekanand We are in the process of changing our registered name from The Spastics Centre Kanpur to Ashayen Centre. Until all the paperwork is completed, we can receive donations only Worldwide Donors Send Cheque/Demand Draft to: The Spastics Centre Kanpur Payable at: Kanpur Mailing Address: The Director, Spastics Centre Kanpur, Bal Bhavan, 16/99-A Phool Bagh, Kanpur 208001, Uttar Pradesh, INDIA Donors in U.S.A can also avail tax-deductions for their generosity! Please send cheque to: Courage Center Mention this on the check: "For the International Fund restricted to the Spastics Centre Kanpur" Mailing Address: Courage Center, 3915 Golden Valley Road, Golden Valley, MN 55422, USA OR For bank transfers: Standard Chartered Bank NY Account No.: 3582088635001 Swift Account: SCBLINBBXXX   For donations through Bank Transfers Account Details: The Spastics Centre Kanpur Account No.: 622-1-003936-1 Standard Chartered Bank, Kanpur, India. Through Routine Banker Standard Chartered Bank, India A/C

item.title: Our services

item.title: About disabilities
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
“The child must know that he is a miracle, that since the beginning of the world there hasn't been, and until the end of the world there will not be, another child like him.” - Pablo Casals
  • Developmental Disability is not a disease but a condition
  • It is neither curable nor contagious but it can be managed. Early intervention can improve outcomes.
  • Many persons with such differences have excelled as authors, sports persons, software professionals, bank managers, scientists and in many other professions

Childhood neurological disorders comprise a group of different conditions that influence brain development. Children may have difficulty with a combination of movement, speech, attention, language and learning. By evaluating each child carefully, one can determine in what capacity their brain has developed differently than average children. In many instances, prompt intervention can lead to improved quality of life, while negligence can lead to deterioration. It is important to recognize that children will continue to develop even when they have a disorder, and proper care will help them develop to the best of their ability.

Disability does not mean inability. These children's obvious impairments often obscure the significant abilities they retain. By focusing on what a child can do, it is possible to bring out their true skills and talents. This involves coordinated care between medical treatment, education, physical therapy and language therapy. Each child is unique and requires a different approach. Depending on the nature of the neurological disorder, each child will benefit from a different set of goals.
Cerebral Palsy
Cerebral Palsy (CP) is group of disorders resulting in problems with movement. CP results from damage to the Cerebrum (brain) resulting in Palsy (paralysis). CP is usually evident during the first three years of life. Symptoms can include muscle rigidity, impaired ability to walk, speech problems and repetitive movements. Many children with CP have normal cognitive function, but may have difficulty performing school tasks like writing or answering questions. Therapy is geared towards improving muscle control and maximizing educational ability.
Autism
Autism is a family of disorders relating to abnormal social development and communication. The exact cause of Autism is not known, but symptoms are usually apparent before a child turns three years old. Children may exhibit repetitive behaviors, difficulty expressing themselves, have trouble focusing in school. Therapy is geared towards language and social skills, as well as building self awareness.

item.title: Volunteer
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded: Ways to give time Since the very beginning Volunteers have played a very important role. Volunteers are firm pillars and their dedication and commitment is a tremendous help to us. “The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the service of others” – Mahatma Gandhi Visit Ashayen Centre to give the gift of time to students and staff by volunteering to help with reading, sports, crafts, music or with the numerous tasks necessary to provide a safe and comfortable environment.

item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin

item.title: Mission and Vision
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
Mission Statement We strive to provide persons with cerebral palsy and other intellectual and physical disabilities with opportunities to recognize and enhance their abilities to attain their maximum potential and integrate into their community, thereby improving their quality of life. Vision Over the next ten years we strive to:
  • Develop outreach centres all over the district
  • Spread awareness for cerebral palsy, mental retardation, autism and multiple disabilities
  • Establish a residential facility

item.title: Who we are
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
The desire to do something for children with disabilities led our Founders to establish, Ashayen Centre, earlier known as The Spastics Centre, Kanpur. We have been serving children and young adults with disabilities since 1990. Ashayen began primarily for children with Cerebral Palsy, but we have broadened our scope over the years to include children with Mental Retardation, Autism and Multiple Disabilities. When it began, ours was the first centre of its kind in Uttar Pradesh. Seeing the progress our children make over the years has proved that “disability does not mean inability”. For society and parents who considered children with handicaps as a burden, our students are an example that with proper training and rehabilitation they can contribute to society. Ashayen, (which means “hopes” in Hindi) is a beacon for hundreds of families in Kanpur, a city that greatly lacks educational and other services for children with intellectual and physical disabilities. When we started in 1990, we had just 21 children. With growing awareness and support from foreign and local donors we are fortunate to be serving more children and young adults each year. In 2012, there were over 250 children in the Physiotherapy department and 125 in the school section. We have been providing services at minimal fees as most of our students come from poor families. Our services, in education and physiotherapy, compare with the best available in India. Ashayen specializes in physiotherapy for those with cerebral palsy and are continually building expertise in handling other disabilities as well. The centre is a place where children from all strata of society, irrespective of race or religion, to engage in learning together. Looking forward, Ashayen strives to reach out to more of this underserved population and continually improve its services. The future plan is to establish more sub centres in neighbouring areas and creating an effective network of outreach centres. The long-term vision is to offer its expertise to surrounding rural areas and smaller towns. Additionally, we would like to become a Resource institution that imparts training to caregivers, teachers and therapists.   Our Affiliations With our long-term association, guidance and training from: Courage Centre, Minneapolis, USA, the Indian Institute of Cerebral Palsy (IICP), Kolkata and Spastic Centre of Northern India (now called AADI), Ashayen Centre continues to incorporate better equipment and medicines to enable them to reach their maximum potential.

  • National Trust, Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

item.title: Success Stories
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded: We take great pleasure in sharing the remarkable achievements of our students. It makes us proud that: many have successfully completed their high school education and a few are pursuing college degrees, some have participated in sports events and won prizes (even on the national level) and there are some have secured employment and are living productive lives. These special children have inspired and keep inspiring all those who come into their lives to keep striving to live meaningfully. Here are the remarkable stories of some of our students. Neha Kumari – She is a young woman who continued her education with Ashayen until she was 25 years old. She came to the Centre at the age of 7 years in the sitting position, unable to walk, stand, speak, sit.  She was totally dependent on her mother for using the toilet and wearing clothes, but now she can do both herself. When she moved she fell and had to wear a helmet on her head to prevent brain damage. Her parents are educated, with a father working in the Ordinance Factory her parents brought her to us at a young age. She used to be crying all the time due to discomfort and was unable to speak. She was diagnosed with Cerebral Palsy with ATNR (Assymetrical Titanic Nerve Reflexes). With this condition one hand would always be in the air while performing any activity.  She was the 4th and the last child in her family with all other siblings being normal and have now become engineers and really cooperate and help Neha. With physiotherapy she began walking and had to have a helmet on. She faltered at first and gradually gained confidence. As she progressed, the helmet was removed. She had near to normal intelligence but was unable to write due to poor hand-eye coordination. With continued training, physiotherapy and her own perseverance she completed high school education with the help of a Writer. She can type rather quickly on the computer and speaks and understands English and Hindi. What is amazing is her ability to remember she teachers and physiotherapists birthdays even when their own family may forget! She makes a card each year for them. Neha enjoys drawing and painting and we have printed her artwork on our cards.

item.title: Press
item.dc:creator: spasticcentreadmin
item.content:encoded:
Many newspapers have supported Ashayen Centre’s efforts by covering various events and dignitary visits. Press coverage helps further our goal of spreading awareness and raising acceptability for disabilities. Most of all, it brings great joy to the children and makes their parents proud to see their pictures in the papers!
Coming soon...news articles and annual reports
